dcterms:title: Inclusion body myositis with early onset: a population-based study
dcterms:abstract: Inclusion body myositis (IBM) is an inflammatory myopathy causing progressive weakness, typically presenting after 45 years of age. This study investigates early-onset IBM, defined by symptom onset before 45. In a population-based cohort of 142 patients, we examined six cases of early-onset IBM, their clinical features, mitochondrial DNA alterations, and survival outcomes.

fabio:hasPart.dcterms:title: Introduction
fabio:hasPart.fabio:hasContent: This section introduces inclusion body myositis (IBM), highlighting the significance of early-onset cases in understanding the disease's progression and clinical features.

fabio:hasPart.dcterms:title: Methods
fabio:hasPart.fabio:hasContent: Details the methods used to identify patients fulfilling the criteria for IBM, including inclusion criteria, diagnostic procedures, and data collection.

fabio:hasPart.dcterms:title: Results
fabio:hasPart.fabio:hasContent: Presents findings related to symptom onset, clinical features, strength decline, and mitochondrial DNA analysis for early-onset IBM patients.

fabio:hasPart.dcterms:title: Conclusion
fabio:hasPart.fabio:hasContent: Summarizes the implications of early-onset IBM and its clinical relevance, highlighting the need for further studies on the condition.

cito:cites.dcterms:title: 188th ENMC International Workshop: Inclusion body myositis
Inclusion body myositis: Clinical features and clinical course of the disease in 64 patients
